page.title: 13Ecology - The Observatory
page.content: While the superb seabird cliffs and colonies of the Isle of May are important in the context of eastern Britain, it is an observatory for the study of migrating birds that the island is world famous. Situated at the crossroads where the north/south and east/west routes meet, the May is a stopping place for thousands of birds of many species on their biannual movements. The observatory was established in 1934, but the island has been used for migration studies since 1907. The work of two Fife ladies, Miss Evelyn Baxter and Miss Leonora Rintoul, from 1907 onwards is still regarded as a major contribution to our knowledge of the factors affecting bird movement in the North Sea area. Nowadays the Observatory is fully manned during the spring and autumn migration period.
